2, 2015
												This is by far one of the greatest star wars games to date. Best know for its advanced lightsaber gameplay mechanics; Jedi Outcast's campaign, which for a new player is about 12-14 hours (8-10 on reply) is a real challenge compared to modern day releases. Some levels require precise gameplay but give you mines, outposts, and city districts to explore, with many hidden treasures.The games main character, Kyle Katarn, is a well loved character in the star wars universe and personally my favourite character. It is a shame the new films might not use him for a role. Levels are challenging, espically on harder difficulties and show a real sense on progression through the unlocking of new force powers and leveling them up.While this game has less customisation then it's sequal, Jedi Acadamy, I still argue this is by far the better game. More interesting story, better villian (Deissan is a bad a**) and has more stand out moments, such as the invasion of the Jedi Temple. The soundtrack comes straight from the films and there is only really one section I have had quarels about, Simply because I don't like the AT-ST which you have to pilot.The multiplayer is also fun and even though many don't play it anymore, you can still take advantage of the game's bot system which was not really matched until Call of Duty: Black Ops combat training mode. There are lots of maps and customisation is great with, saber's powers and character skins and dyes. Overall a great game and is incredible good value. A classic gamer without having this on their play list is really missing out. 9.8/10

content:
ber 30, 2015
												Ladies and gents, the page you are looking at is the final destination of the very first TRUE Star Wars game.Jedi Outcast is still today regarded as the closest a game has ever gotten to capturing the experience of being a Jedi. Before the perfectly functional but not-revolutionary sequel Jedi Academy, which pads its gameplay out with gimmicks like duo lightsabers and double-bladed models, this game simply features a rugged, complex hero with a single blue lightsaber burning his way through every hive of scum and villany in the galaxy to seek revenge on the most intimidating Sith Lord to come from the post-Empire era and stop a plot that convieniently involves the generation of dark jedi, providing great deals of fodder for epic saber clashes on levels that still embarass most developers in terms of complexity and depth and still stand with dignity in terms of appearance. But perhaps the most engaging part of the game are the first few levels, where you begin not as a Jedi but a common Mercenary, Han Solo in all but name, running rings around Stormtroopers by the seat of your own wit. And that brings me to the best way I can sell you this game: Jedi Outcast is the perfect game incarnation of the original trilogy.

content:
er 24, 2016
												A nice little third-/first-person romp from back before Raven Software did something other than porting previous Call of Duty maps to whichever one just came out. Jedi Academy is technically a better game by virtue of giving you the lightsaber right away and not punishing you with a level filled with five-hundred snipers before you actually get to enjoy using it. From a story standpoint, though, I like this one better mostly for that it actually gets pretty dark for a Star Wars game that's not KOTOR II - basically every situation you come in on has been ♥♥♥♥ed from the get-go, and there's not a whole lot you're able to do about it until you get strong enough to take the fight to the enemy.Also, nominate this for the last award under "Best Unintentional Use of Shadows". If you're not playing this with the ill-fitting volumetric shadows that float high in the air half the time and make the game look like killer7 the other half, then you're not playing this correctly.

content:
er 15, 2015
												To this date, Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy (and their much different, much older predecessor, Dark Forces 2: Jedi Knight) remain two of the best Star Wars games available.  Both based on the old Quake 3 engine, they feature a unique take on lightsaber combat and boast an authentic Original Trilogy feel.  Multiplayer still works (it doesn't rely on developer servers), and can be used online or with LAN buddies.  Still runs stable on Windows 7, tho a few CFG tweaks are needed for modern screen resolutions (thanks, WSGF).  If you're looking for some good Star Wars games, or just some good games in general, don't pass this series up!Note that most of my time in this game was spent in a non-Steam copy, back before Steam had become what it is now.

content:
ry 9, 2015
												Initially I gave this game a negative review, but after giving Dark Forces a try and replaying Force Unleashed and then this, I'm feeling a lot more charitable towards it.While my old criticisms still stand (the lightsaber duels being basically luck-based, a few overpowered enemies (particularly the snipers and the grenade-spamming space goats), and the stealth mission being the absolute worst idea the devs ever had), and while I still think that Jedi Academy has more polished gameplay, Jedi Outcast is still a very well put together installment, and considerably more substantial (Jedi Academy mostly being a series of brief "episodes" with full levels marking the main acts).Interestingly, I find the game is at its best in the first two levels before you get any Force powers, where you're basically playing a graphically enhanced, more linear expansion to the original Dark Forces, making me feel oddly nostalgic about callbacks to a game I only played a few weeks ago. The level design is tighter there, giving the locales a sense of continuity and scale that later parts of the game are simply lacking. I think this can be attributed to the fact that with things like Force Jump in your arsenal, the developers felt they needed to give you wide-open spaces with which to take advantage of it, which turns the levels into the "squiggly linear corridor" school of lazy level design.Even so, the levels are still fairly varied in their design, even if they feel more... "gamey" for a lack of a better word. Setpieces, not locations. Especially with the rampant Bottomless Pit abuse. Include more than one completely nonsensical example where you know said pit couldn't possibly fit in the dimensions of the location you're in, like onboard the Doomgiver, a ship that's maybe 5 stories tall at most given the orbital drop pods visible on its underside.But that's nitpicking. The Dark Forces Saga is still probably the most EU-friendly entry into the Star Wars gaming library, and Kyle Katarn is still likable badass. Jedi Outcast is not without its major flaws, but if you can stomach them I can't in good conscience call it a bad game.

content:
7, 2015
												Best Star Wars game I have ever played. It was a brilliant FPS/TPS at the time, and one of the first that I ever played. Graphics were amazing, the level design is just incredible and of course, the lightsaber battles have yet to be matched in quality. Trust me, this game may be old, but it's the most underrated game I have ever seen. I would totally buy this if it were remastered, but I'll settle for the Steam rerelease.The amount of love in this game is fantasic, the levels are long and challenging, the gameplay is still amazing, the multiplayer is dead, but worth finding a game for, and is one of the most satisfying things to kill an enemy with the lightsaber. The first level you use it in is awful admittedly, because who the hell makes the first level with a lightsaber contain enemies that use sniper rifles and grenades? But really, this game has the best lightsaber gameplay in any Star Wars game.

content:
er 23, 2015
												When I was a kid I always wanted to be a Jedi. I mean, what's better than running with laser sword, cutting heads of plastic robots and using magic on right and left. But how would be it possible, when it is impossible. Well, it was impossible before "Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Outcast" been released. Jedi Outcast story, would be placed between Episode 6 and new Episode 7. When look Skywalker is already grown and powerful Jedi and he made his new academy to recruit and train new padawans. In the game we play as Kyle Katarn, the young rebel who's fate intertwined with the force, earlier mentioned Luke and his new weapon by his side. He also meets all of previous characters from old Star Wars saga like for example Lando. Once we unite with main character we have the feelings like we were a Jedi ourselves. That's why I love this game even today.  It's been 14 years since this game came out, therefore we can't rate Jedi Outcast by graphics. However, even today in my opinion the game  looks decent. We have plenty of lights, effective light sabers, pretty good models. Everything seems like we would be there.Good dubbing and the music isn't bad either. We can feel the climate of previously themes made by John Williams and each of them are on right place.I don't think there i a game with better gameplay then this. Some people would say that KOTOR is the best game of universe, but I'm opposed. Just like I mentioned before we feel like a Jedi, it is done by real time Lightsaber fighting. Where we can even chose its style we can starring the side we want to hit, and we can chose Jedi and Sith forces during fights with our enemies. May be I was a bit nostalgic during writing this review, but to be honest I don't think there will be better Star Wars game. If you never play it, you should have.11/10

14, 2015
												A good, if not particularly elegant, Star Wars game that smooths some of the creases of Jedi Knight, and contains many creases of its own that are subsequently smoothed over in Jedi Outcast. Better graphics and more fluid and varied swordplay are tempered by confusing and unintuitive level design, some cringeworthy animation, and dumb-as-a-post enemy AI. You have to tinker with it to get it to fit widescreen monitors, but overall it's a long and satisfying game that capably pushed the series into the next generation. But seriously though -  god damn, I'd forgotten how f**king difficult this game is. 7 smashed keyboards out of 10.

content:
22, 2015
												Действие игры разворачивается спустя три года после событий Mysteries of the Sith. Боясь вновь соблазниться темной стороной Силы, Кайл Катарн отказывается от неё и своего светового меча. Он вновь работает простым наёмником на Новую Республику, вместе с Джен Орс, участвуя в разгроме последних сил имперского Остатка. Во время очередной миссии Кайл и Джен встречают тёмного джедая Десанна, который, узнав известного джедая — победителя грозного Джерека — похищает Джен. Кайл пытается помешать ему, но Десанн легко справляется с ним при помощи Силы и заставляет Кайла убедиться в гибели своей соратницы.Кайл в ярости решает вновь стать джедаем и отправляется в Долину Джедаев, где снова получает Силу. Он не знает, что Десанн все время следил за ним и теперь знает расположение Долины. Кайл же летит на Явин IV, в академию джедаев, чтобы забрать у Люка Скайуокера свой световой меч. Люк заставляет Кайла пройти несколько испытаний, и только затем вручает Катарну его меч. Люк наводит для него справки и помогает выйти на крупного бизнесмена в сфере мусоропереработки, Рило Барука, который помогает Кайлу выйти на след Десанна. На базе Рило Катарн встречает одного из лидеров повстанцев — Лэндо Калриссиана, который находится в плену. Освободив его, герой попадает в Облачный город, где по воле случая встречает Тавион Аксмис — ученицу Десанна. В схватке Кайл побеждает её. Однако перед тем, как Кайл собирался убить её, она успевает раскрыть все планы учителя и то, что Джен живая содержится на флагмане Остатка, «Хозяин судеб». Кайл пощадил её, так как понял, что если в гневе убить Тавион, он может пасть на тёмную сторону.В планы Десанна входило с помощью особых технологий создать армию «Возрождённых» (обычные бойцы, искусственным путём наделённые Силой). Собрав немалые силы, имперцы намеревались уничтожить всех джедаев, а также разрушить Долину джедаев. Кайл проникает на флагман и освобождает Джен. Попутно он встречает Люка, который шёл по следам Десанна (не сумел однажды в бою его одолеть). С «Хозяина судеб» Катарн подаёт сигнал флоту Новой республики и истребители уничтожают флагман, а Кайл убивает его командира — Галака Файера.На Явине IV Кайл пробирается через джунгли из капсулы, на которой сбежал с погибающего крейсера Остатка. В жестоких боях с «Возрождёнными» погибает немало джедаев. Под Академией Кайл находит Десанна, который воспользовался агрегатом Силы и стал ещё мощнее. Кайл говорит ему о безнадёжности ведения войны, и что все его воины уничтожены. Десанн ему не верит, но связывается с адмиралом. Тот не отвечает, и Десанн приходит в ярость. Он пытается склонить Кайла на тёмную сторону, но в ответ он предлагает Десанну самому вернуться на светлую сторону. Тёмный джедай, придя в ещё большую ярость, включает свой меч и бросается в атаку. В тяжёлой дуэли Кайл одолевает его.После этих событий он с Джен отправляется на отдых, после чего возвращается к преподаванию в академии.

content:
, 2015
												I personally disliked Jedi Outcast years ago (I played it in 2006 or so for the first time) and after these years I still have mixed feelings about this game. It's not a good shooter. Compared to Dark Forces 2 (I managed to run it off Steam some time ago) it's bland and irritiating. Heck, even compared to Dark Forces 1 it's lacking, and Dark Forces 1 has an auto-aim. Probably because weapons in this game (except sniper rifle and basic blaster) are so inaccurate and their power feels off it doesn't feel much different from having the auto-aim in the first game in the series. Also, being more of a 3rd person action game, the movement while in 1st person mode will cost you life many times after slipping off the ledge.Yeah, this game is all about lightsaber ♥♥♥♥. But it's hard to recommend Jedi Outcast now, since Jedi Academy is plain better in that matter. While Dark Forces 2 balanced shooter and slasher gameplay pretty well, Jedi Outcast sacrificed shooting in favor of lightsaber ♥♥♥♥ (after all these years of terrible lightsabers sounds and their exploitation everywhere I grew to hate lightsabers and everything connected with them). I dunno - compared to Jedi Academy, saber fighting with AI gets my nerves off. Maybe the multiplayer is the reason I had remembered it well, up until I launched it now. While in Jedi Academy I enjoyed almost an every lightsaber fight, in Jedi Outcast I'm willing cut my wrists fighting Reborns or bosses. It's significantly less accurate than Dark Forces 2 saber fighting (and shooting for that matter).Level design is pretty good. It's not amazing, but it's not a walk down the corridor all the way. The first levels in the game are the best ones, with the exception of Nar Shaddaa (the only level where the shooting is bearable), while the rest of them (♥♥♥♥ing Bespin) are just a show-off arenas connected with corridors to force more lightsaber fighting and jumping around every corner. At the end of the day, it's nothing to write home about, and the lack of map is sometimes annoying (the previous games have maps).And there's the story. It's a typical expanded universe's mania of writing (stuff from there mostly exists solely to make money from sad, exceptional people who can't define themselves without connecting to a commercial diarrhea) rubbish that destroyed the original Star Wars theme,It's not a bad game, not at all, but compared to every other title in the series - it's an obviously sub-par title which got stuck between genres. This game works best on cheats on, off the campaign and off the multiplayer, messing with force powers, cutting enemies in pieces.

content:
er 11, 2016
												+ worlds, ambience, music, environment.+ weapons's choice+ The force + The protagonist, Kyle+ The supporting characters+ Most levels are really well made and diverse.- cannot choose between jedi and sith side.- Luke, Desann, Tavion and other Jedi really act h0m0s in this game.- Desann, the antagonist truly lacks of depth. He looks badass but we don't know much about him. Why did he turn sith ? How come Luke and other jedi masters failed to notice he was turning sith; it's not like the academy had more than 10 students.- Some levels are more boring than others. They usually contain painstaking enigmas that will slow your progression in the story.9/10Jedi knight Outcast 2 is my childhood love affair ! I often recall the game with my friends since then. The game as a whole is just hilarious, whether it is intended or not. Whether it is Jan's sarcasmes on Kyle or Kyle's cheesy lines or those weird death screams, you will laugh ! The gameplay is also fun ! You can almost fly with the jump power, you can neutralise enemies by pulling their weapons towards you or instead push them overboard. Weapons are also fun to use. The crossbow is pretty useless though. You will come across many world. Kejim, Nar Shaada, Yavin, imperial ships... The developers put a real effort on the level design. Each imperial base look different from the another. Enemies are also various. You come across different class of sith, imperial officers, or troopers. The game gives you the impression of a coherent world happening.The only real criticism I can make about this game is that the game does not offer any real alternatives as being a jedi. Kyle will remain benevolent the entire game, and will never turn sith. That's a pity. In a sense this game is a little too childish for me like most recent star wars movies. The good is good the bad is bad. Grey zones do not exist. In this regards KOTOR actually approaches such nuances in a much better way. In fact each character in KOTOR provide rational arguments whether they support or oppose jedi, it is up to you to make a choice. In Jedi Knight Outcast 2 that freedom does not exist.9/10

content:
y 4, 2016
												Juego que en su tiempo lo jugué en Xbox, y que todavía me trae recuerdos de mi adolescencia. La campaña tiene una duración decente, y vencer el juego en dificultad Jedi Master es toda una hazaña. La historia es una de las clásicas del universo expandido de Star Wars, siendo la secuela directa de Star Wars: Dark Forces II, y nos da un panorama diferente de que es posible infundir los poderes de la Fuerza en seres no sensibles (por un momento me hace querer uno de los cristales para mí :'c ) y como se usan éstos para usarlos contra los Jedi por un Jedi oscuro como Desann. En este juego se nos enseña y nos da la posibilidad a utilizar muchos poderes de la Fuerza, como el rayo o estrangulación (mi favorito), cosa que fue innovadora para su época. En fin, la historia se me hace exquisita y hubiera preferido que Disney hubiera hecho algo como ésto en lugar de sacar la ♥♥♥♥♥♥ de The Force Awakens :p La jugabilidad es buena salvo por unas cosas:- Es imposible ajustar a una sensibilidad adecuada al ratón, no hay precisión en ese sentido, tienes que jugar con sensibilidad mínima y aún así se siente demasiado sensible.-Los controles son muy incómodos por la gran cantidad de armas y poderes y no hay teclas suficientes o al menos cómodas que garantizen una jugabilidad excelente.-Siempre que quería tomar un screenshot, el juego se autoguardaba, incómodo al principio, se tiene que modificar en cuanto empiezas el juego.-El multijugador sigue estando vivo, aunque es raro encontrar un servidor de más de 10 personas y/o con un ping abajo de  50, pero el detalle es que encuentras jugadores buenísimos con muchísima experiencia por delante, o muy malos que  sólo saben atacar con el sable de luz. Aún con esos jugadores la maestría absoluta del sable de luz es casi imposible y te garantizan que en las partidas hasta un noob como yo puede ganar (es en serio, gané varias partidas).Recomendado aún sí  no eres fan de Star Wars.GGWP

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												The best part about this game is hacking and slashing through a bunch of storm troopers within an extended universe story that (for my knowledge) doesn't exist anymore. You'll enjoy the horrid animations of the early 2000s, janky controls which need to be formatted, and unbelievably annoying and unfair lightsaber battles with NPCs who taunt you like a kid on the playground.  There are some things to keep in mind though, especially if you are looking to play this game:-	You automatically deflect blaster shots and even on a harder difficulty the enemies are generally coded by a six year old child and run into you instead of for cover -	Most of your deaths will be caused either by the environment or snipers who are immune to saber deflection (you need to counter-snipe them) -	Unless you’re using a mod for textures on the environments, you have an easier time navigating this game while drunk-	Unless you edit it in settings you automatically switch to third person to use your lightsaber. I mean, I guess you can play like that if you enjoy being a baby doofus. -	Some of the best dialogue in the game isn’t in the cut scenes but between storm troopers before they notice you’re coming up on them. Makes you feel bad that you need to kill them, especially since you can take more time getting to know different Stormtroopers on an emotional level than the girl you need to save because of some stupid tied in love story no one could honestly care about-	You can’t pick your lightsaber color in the story mode. Like really? Really? The character customization was the best part of the first one, even if the story was just as stupid. -	The weapons which are Star Wars staples that people recognize are the lightsabers, E-11, bow caster, and thermal detonator. The rest are made up to make the game feel more like doom. And 90% of the time you only use the lightsaber anyway so….-	Oh yeah, the story is stupid. You go to like, 6 places really. -	I think the story is a continuation of Jedi Academy? -	I’m pretty sure that’s not Billy Dee Williams voicing Lando in this one. Sorry guys. All in all, the game is worth a few bucks. If you’re smart you’ll convince your friends to buy it too so you can spend countless minutes hacking each other apart in a multiplayer server (if you set one up) before you all retire to play Gary’s Mod and look at memes. I give Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast a solid 2.5/5 stars, not because of how bad or good it is, but because it reminds me of that kid who was supposed to be in remedial math, but was placed in honors because his older brother was on the varsity soccer team and his mom was banging the principal. Even though it falls short, it still gains merit because it has the Star Wars badge slapped over it. If it was any other universe or franchise, I could easily produce more effort to give up living  via onset aneurism then play this game. In conclusion, I recommend this game because it helps you waste time on this pathetic rock known as Earth while dragging you across the universe on a story that doesn't really matter. You kill guys who don't like you because you don't like them, and in the end, isn't that what life is all about?        (Final Rating=   **.5 / *****)

content:
, 2016
												I absolutely could not stop playing this game. Usually I play a game and get bored, then I have to switch to another, but not this one. I just made it to the last level and thought this would be a great time to review without spoilers.  You will die a lot and love it. This has to be the best light saber battle game out there right beside Star Wars Jedi Knight Academy. The graphics are a little out of date but still immerse you into the game.The story so far is right on spot and has an original feel just like Academy did. The level design is a little crazy because you have to actually figure out how to get places, it's not just a straight line. You have to rely on your senses there is no highlighted or flashing graphics telling you how to progress.This is one of those games where you have to save every time you take a step. If not a Sith will jump out behind you and end your existence. At one level in the game you come up to a door and when it opens you are scared to **** by Luke Skywalker. I would let him jump down and kill a Stormtrooper again lol.I recommend this at regular price and on sale, definitely worth it.

content:
, 2016
												The best part about this game is hacking and slashing through a bunch of storm troopers within an extended universe story that (for my knowledge) doesn't exist anymore. You'll enjoy the horrid animations of the early 2000s, janky controls which need to be formatted, and unbelievably annoying and unfair lightsaber battles with NPCs who taunt you like a kid on the playground.  There are some things to keep in mind though, especially if you are looking to play this game:-	You automatically deflect blaster shots and even on a harder difficulty the enemies are generally coded by a six year old child and run into you instead of for cover -	Most of your deaths will be caused either by the environment or snipers who are immune to saber deflection (you need to counter-snipe them) -	Unless you’re using a mod for textures on the environments, you have an easier time navigating this game while drunk-	Unless you edit it in settings you automatically switch to third person to use your lightsaber. I mean, I guess you can play like that if you enjoy being a baby doofus. -	Some of the best dialogue in the game isn’t in the cut scenes but between storm troopers before they notice you’re coming up on them. Makes you feel bad that you need to kill them, especially since you can take more time getting to know different Stormtroopers on an emotional level than the girl you need to save because of some stupid tied in love story no one could honestly care about-	You can’t pick your lightsaber color in the story mode. Like really? Really? The character customization was the best part of the first one, even if the story was just as stupid. -	The weapons which are Star Wars staples that people recognize are the lightsabers, E-11, bow caster, and thermal detonator. The rest are made up to make the game feel more like doom. And 90% of the time you only use the lightsaber anyway so….-	Oh yeah, the story is stupid. You go to like, 6 places really. -	I think the story is a continuation of Jedi Academy? -	I’m pretty sure that’s not Billy Dee Williams voicing Lando in this one. Sorry guys. All in all, the game is worth a few bucks. If you’re smart you’ll convince your friends to buy it too so you can spend countless minutes hacking each other apart in a multiplayer server (if you set one up) before you all retire to play Gary’s Mod and look at memes. I give Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast a solid 2.5/5 stars, not because of how bad or good it is, but because it reminds me of that kid who was supposed to be in remedial math, but was placed in honors because his older brother was on the varsity soccer team and his mom was banging the principal. Even though it falls short, it still gains merit because it has the Star Wars badge slapped over it. If it was any other universe or franchise, I could easily produce more effort to give up living  via onset aneurism then play this game. In conclusion, I recommend this game because it helps you waste time on this pathetic rock known as Earth while dragging you across the universe on a story that doesn't really matter. You kill guys who don't like you because you don't like them, and in the end, isn't that what life is all about?        (Final Rating=   **.5 / *****)

content:
2016
												Well, this is THE posterboy star wars game at the time it was released, and It is one of the most memorable experiences i've ever had with a Star Wars game. Among all the games I play in modern times that include Halo 5 and Battlefield 4, this game is the most memorable of them all. Man, I just could'nt believe the stensil shadow engine and physics at that time, throwing troopers around, the quality first person experience, story elements that were technically above the rest at the time, the authentic sound effects, and general pacing of the game. It was just incredible, and to prove that to myself in modern day, I've purchased and installed this game again recently and started playing again. I played this ♥♥♥♥ on a geforce mx back around 2000! Such fond memories then and now, woohoo! For someone who hasn't played this game back then, it won't have the same meaning. I'm sorry for that. For the few of us that did, let us band together and experience a collective evolution in gaming that really made a difference in the future of 3rd person and 1st person experiences.

content:
y 3
												Besteht den Test der Zeit leider nicht. Wie schon Jedi Knight ist auch Jedi Knight 2 heute einfach nicht mehr zu empfehlen. Doch während bei Teil 1 das Leveldesign für den Allerwertesten ist, ist bei der Fortsetzung noch einiges mehr schiefgegangen. Es fängt ja schonmal bei den viel zu schwachen und ungenauen Waffen an. Man hält dem Gegner einen E11 Blaster ins Gesicht und schießt, verfehlt aber trotzdem. Dann kommt noch das ultraschlampige Leveldesign, das noch schlimmer als das von Teil 1 ist. Scheinbar muss man im Star Wars Universum dauernd durch Lüftungsschächte kriechen und von Dächern springen, wenn man eine Bar besuchen will. Wäre was für Fait...Und dann wäre da noch das billige Spieldesign. Kommt der Spieler voran, spawnen einfach Dutzende Gegner und gefühlte 1000 Schuss später sind dann alle tot und ich vor Langeweile fast eingeschlafen. Sobald man das Lichtschwert hat wird das Spiel zum reinsten Spaziergang, da man nebenher auch noch die Macht wieder eingesammelt hat und Gegner herumwerfen kann. Wenn Sie einen Star Wars Shooter spielen möchten, empfehle ich Dark Forces und Republic Commando. Die machen auch heute noch Spaß! Und falls es was von Raven Software sein sollte, empfehle ich Soldier of Fortune 1+2, Star Trek Voyager Elite Force, Singularity und Wolfenstein.

content:
, 2016
												I appreciate that you have to play older games with a certain eye, particularly those from the early days of 3D, and in some ways it can be interesting to see what has been lost from that era. Sprawling levels full of secrets, fast movement and twitch based aiming are all sadly mostly gone from the modern shooter. Jedi Knight 2 is a throw back to that era, and it is terrible.Let’s start with the worst offender - The level design, which is just mind blowingly horrible. The first two levels leave you lightsaberless in a selection of featureless bland, grey corridors fighting stormtroopers that mill around like jackbooted schoolkids. The levels are massive, unintuitive mazes with no map screen, and the game constantly breaks it’s own rules – at one point you have to blow up a barrel to burn out a switch. None of the other barrels in the game up until that point have done anything to switches when they blew up nearby, so why the ♥♥♥♥ would this one?The weapons, outside of the lethal glowstick are pretty much universally rubbish, a bunch of unsatisfying weightless guffpumpers, made worse by enemy feedback, or the lack of it – they seem to just absorb fire until they remember to keel over dead. The stormtrooper rifle is at least lore accurate – you won’t be hitting ♥♥♥♥ with it unless at point blank range, and even then it’s touch and go. The grenades are laughably terrible as well, exploding with all the force and thunder of a damp dog fart.If you grit your teeth through six hours of this, you finally get your lightsaber and some force powers. Things are looking up – you can now cut down fools and reflect blaster shots! The level after your Jedi trial? A city full of narrow walkways and infuriating pixel accurate snipers that can’t be blocked. This is a soul sapping chore, made rage inducing by the god-awful platforming – Kyle Katarn appears to have greased up his shoes, and will fly off a platform at even the slightest prompt. Even more bafflingly, you can prevent this by holding down the use button, necessitating strange hand contortions. Why? What possible reason could the devs have to not have this on at all times? In what situation do you WANT to skid around like you’re moonwalking in a bacon factory?There are those that will defend the game based on its story. They are wrong. The cutscenes, featuring terrifying Star Wars mannequins as animated by Monty Python, are at least amusing in their incompetence. Kyle Katarn has always been the universe’s most rubbish Jedi (and he’s got stiff competition post prequels), but here he’s almost painfully uninteresting, a scowling, badly animated beard with a rubbish dead girlfriend.

content:
y 19, 2016
												Dark Forces 1 & 2 are my favorite Star Wars games, ever. As you imagine with the negative raiting, it's with much dismay to say that I can't even bother finishing Dark Forces 3: Jedi Knight 2 (Jedi Outcast). Before you think that I'm complaining about the monotinous beginning, know that I got 4/5 hours in with getting to Bespin. I got the lightsaber and the force-powers, and even then playing this game felt more of a punishment than a reward.No matter whatever improvements were made in the Lightsaber gameplay and Force abilities they do not save this game. The level-design is cryptically linear, the story is uninteresting and relies too much on canon, and the game focuses solely on the light-saber combat, making your arsenal worthless.The Qualities to EnjoyLight-saber combat in 3rd person is superbly refined with more fluid movement.Force powers are more conviently selected. (Ex. The Force Jump is just the jump-button held longer.)Visuals and scenary can still be enjoyable for what they are. The multiplayer gameplay is very entertaining for what little I played, but I hear that Jedi Academy is where the fans play online with more popularity. (As well as mods.)The Outcast from Dark ForcesNothing about this game other than Kyle Katarn is reminiscent of the previous games' quality. It's an entirely different game that looks, sounds and plays the same, but it all a facade for a tech-demo thinking it's an improvement to the series.That sounds like a lot of nostalgia talking, doesn't it? Well, no; I can say for certain that the two games are more different than alike because I played them alongside one-another: I got about 4 hours into Jedi Knight 2 before I decided to boot up Jedi Knight 1 for about two hours. (Know that I hadn't played the game for over a year, and I'm sure I do not have that good of a memory). In about two hours from JK 1, I was already equipped with my light-saber and happily making it through the dam area mixing up my combat style with blasters and the light-saber. By hour two of JK2, I was looking up an IGN wiki guide because I didn't realize there was an explosive barrel unseen to blow the entrance to the next area. It then occurred to me that no matter how lost I got in JK1, I never recall ever looking up a guide. Because the level-design guided me, subtly, the same way the player is guided in a game like Half-Life where environments and visual cues told this information to the player. (Also, I had a map on me to figure out my location if I ever lost my way.)Both of those qualities are absent in JK2. Something I cannot but help to attribute to a change of developers from LucasArts to Raven Software during LA's change from making games to licencing them.In JK2, you have no map, period; no briefing to show the map or an in-game map to help. And far too often you'll have to blow up this wall from a specific corner, to jump into a trash-compactor to get to the other side, or to do something so convuluted it ruins any sense of exploration. What makes JK2 worse is how it has detached itself from its Doom/Dark Forces roots of exploring out of necessity for healh, items and ammo. You'll typically find everything littered on the floors, especially health and shield-stations. (Not that you'll need a lot of ammo once you get the light-saber.) Another major change is how the lightsaber is so vital that I think it's to the detriment of the game. Except for the sniper-rifle which is used for those cheap sharp-shooters who can see you a mile away, the game sends enemies at you with large amounts of health that the light-saber becomes essential as an offensive and defensive weapon. Combine the light-saber with the Force abilities to knock down or disperse enemies--which are no longer unlocked by your choices but automatically unlocked for you--and the game quickly becomes stale by the constant woosh of the lightsaber. (Admittedly, the visceral sound of the lightsaber is the best thing about JK2.)These changes, combined with the smaller level designs, all serve to disappoint any fan who became fond of the first two games (and expansion) because they sacrifice the complexity of the old games for the sake of graphic and gameplay enhancements.An Arsenal of One is An Arsenal of NoneThe thing about JK2 that surprised me the most is how quickly I became tired of using the lightsaber. Far too often I found that running around and slashing through enemies would be the best strategy for winning.Outside of the Sniper Rifle for those cheap snipers that can spot you a mile away, the weapons you find become a deteriment to you than a benefit. It's interesting how both games have the exact same combat and guns, but small tweaks to the gameplay completely change what is the best playstyle.If there are tons of enemies, you cannot move around as nimbly as in JK1 (without spamming the Speed ability) to make range combat useful. Also, despite how "accurate" the Stormtroopers' fire their weapons, the enemy AI simply do not account for you mowing through them with the lightsaber or have enemy types to discourage you running into gunfire.For example, in JK 1 the Probes were typically placed far away or would explode when you destroyed them that taking them out by other means was always the better option. The only enemy that is potentially a hazard when running into are the grenaders, which can be easily remedied by using Force Push/Pull. (The exception being the snipers, which are so cheap that running past them can sometimes be the better solution for the terrible sniper controls.)As much as I love the improved lightsaber combat, I think it's another reason why you wont part with it because you can rely on blocking most attacks (not relying as much on your aim like JK1.)I'm sure had I pushed farther I would have used the rocket-launcher on some enemy groups or bosses, but this change goes to show how something similar in concept has been changed without paying attention to what was done before.Another Star Wars Game That Can't Forget About Star WarsThis is a more subjective criticism, but I hate how much JK2 serves to fall back on canon to make the story interesting. Luke Skywalker, Lando, Bespin, Yavin are all just thrown into Kyle Katarn's story for the sake of giving the plot any interest.The original Dark Forces had the right idea: Introduce a beginning that ties into the canon, relate that to the audience with the new character, and then create a new story. Jedi Knight 1 also understood this was the best solution for making a Star Wars game refreshing by having a mention of Skywalker and the story of the Valley of the Jedi as the focus.JK2 decides to have you wander around Skywalker's Academy as well as talking to him, and then later fighting alongside him with dozens of Dark Jedi (the only reason I may continue some later day.) You have a similar meet-up with Lando.I would be fine with these fan-services had Katarn's story been given anything interesting. In short, the game gives him another revenge story where he walks along the path of a Jedi/Sith. (Except there is no good/bad ending, something I'm not going to complain about because the good endings were always the real ending.) The plot only serves to put him back on the path of a Jedi when he decided to give it up after he was corrupted from the Dark Side. That's the only inclusion of Outcast that I appreciate as it keeps the focus on Katarn, and not the series itself, but I can't help to question if it was for nothing.Somewhere There's Still Good in Him...I'm mad that I cannot enjoy this game as other fans. The reinfinements to the gameplay, albeit some floaty movement controls, serve to remind me that if I could look past the game's lacking qualities I could find something to love.

												This game failed to entertain me thusfar, queing disappointments instead. You can not create your own character, and are stuck in the least interesting character of the previous installment: Kyle. Secondly, you don't get a lightsaber. Not until you passed several, long levels in a 1st person shooter with elements of a platform and puzzle game. content:
ry 14, 2016
												If you want to ice-skate around pitch black hallways looking for that obscure barrel or button that blends in perfectly with the scenery while enemies peck away at your health with hit-scan weapons and grenades, this is perfect for you.I honestly can't see the fun in this, usually games play off their strengths and you can overlook the weaknesses, but in this game it plays completely off its weaknesses. You spend the first few hours walking around hallways looking for buttons that blend in with the scenery perfectly, by the time you learn what the button generally looks like they change it, you don't get the lightsaber in these few hours, you just spray wildly at things right infront of you. There's a decent Doom-like progression of weapons which leads you to believe you'll be using them a lot, you won't. I used the pistol and bowcaster once, the E-11 and sniper are the only blaster-type weapons I needed.Once you get the lightsaber, you will be pumped, you will want to hack/slash and duel, you will want to master it. Too bad, from this moment on you're against bombers who drop a grenade on death and snipers whose shots can't be deflected by the lightsaber, so you'll be sticking with blasters yet again, but atleast you own the lightsaber now. You will also be doing a lot of jumping puzzles, this is absolute hell because your character is on rollerskates and when you land you slide a bit thus falling off platforms is an easy thing to do. Yet there are a number of jumping puzzles in this game, as I said, they're playing off the weaknesses.The level design is even worse, I ended up watching a walkthrough where the guy doing the walkthrough had to stop to look up a walkthrough. I managed to get up to the waste disposal part before getting too frustrated, I had to blow up a random barrel that could only be shot via a grate and it made me realise I didn't have the patience. there are a lot of trip mines in random places for no other reason than to kill you for not noticing. My first 5 minutes of this game was walking into a store room to instantly blow up, it forces you to save every 5 minutes (each save seems to go to a new file, so have fun with that).The game supports 2k resolution, yet not 1080p, it hates multiple monitors and I can't change the brightness to actually see what I'm doing. I installed this on my SSD yet it takes 10 seconds to load a save which gets frustrating when you're constantly loading a save before a stupid jump or an encounter with an oddly placed bomber and if you alt-tab it will constantly put itself infront of everything else making the essential task of looking at a walkthrough that much harder.I can't say the same for the other games I bought in the bundle, but I'd give this one a miss, I've read that there's a forced stealth segment coming up so my hopes of it getting better were severely misguided.

, 2015
												I kept hearing about how Jedi Outcast is far superior to Jedi Academy, and since I loved last Jedi Knight game and completed it multiple times, I decided to give this one a go, especially since it was already sitting in my library after I bought a bundle. This game has one of the worst openings to a single player campaign I've seen  First level in a nutshell:  lack of a solid narrative hook  extremely generic base, corridor-ridden level design one horrendously inaccurate weapon to use throughout series of mind-numbingly boring button pushing-based  objectives  terrible platforming (WHY ON EARTH IS KYLE SLIDING AFTER EVERY SINGLE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ STEP HE MAKES) idiotically cryptic puzzles (shooting an exploding box that destroys a switch which in turn causes the doors to open? Who came up with that?) two types of extremely dull enemies  WHERE IS MY LIGHTSTABER GODDAMMITI've heard that it gets better past a certain point and I believe that, but honestly the beginning did all it could to discourage me from trying to progress this far, so I have no intention to continue playing this game. Maybe I'll finish it when I feel like driving myself mad again with constant sliding off the ledges and shooting waves of braindead AI with an unimpressive pea shooter, but based on what I've seen I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who wants more than  just a slice of nostalgia out of it.

content:
er 14, 2015
The GoodThis is the first Star Wars game with proper lightsaber combat. You twist, you turn, you almost feel as if the saber is an extension of kyle's body. You block shots with it, you lop body parts off - it's nearly perfect. Sadly, you don't get it until a couple of missions in, but the saber shenangians are the best part of this game.Multiplayer, when anyone uses it, is a blast, but you're better served by the (misleadingly named) Jedi Knight Academy, which is actually a sequel to this game.Headshotting stormtroopers never gets old, neither does doing the same with the mouthy "die rebel scum" blackshirts.Overall, the game is very fun, and I really wanted to like it, but unfortunately...The BadThe game starts out excellent (raiding an Empire base), but just about everything after the first mission is an exercise in bad level design and frustration - learn and love the quicksave/quickload keys because it's very easy to take a wrong step and find yourself redoing half the level.Checkpoints are too far away from each other - a death, unless you're save scumming, means repeating substantial sections of levels.The music. It's the Star Wars music you all know and love, but the problem is *that's all* there is. Every single event in the game is set to the orchestral soundtrack from the original trilogy. It's rather unimaginative, and in many cases, ruins the mood.Difficulty is all over the place. The first mission is a cakewalk, the third is a ragefest. (Insta-kill snipers pls go and stay go)Graphics are remarkably dated, and requires file hacks to enable widescreen support.Nobody plays the multiplayer.OverallA good game irrevocably stuck in the shell of a poorly designed one. I can't recommend it at full price - get it on sale.

content:
r 11, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I've always been a huge fan of LucasArts games, and Star Wars games in general. I'd heard a lot about this game, so I bought it and tried it out. Here's the thing: Most of the positive reviews I've read on Steam for this game are people who played it when they were younger on the GameCube and loved it. I never had that opportunity, and so I was not playing this through rosey colored nostalgia glasses. Upon opening the game, it crashed immediately. After researching for about an hour, had to download a file from a website into a certain area in the code. Fixed the game. Then, after playing for an hour, crashed repeatedly again. Found another fix, and that helped. The first few chapters restrict you to just blaster usage, like in the Dark Forces games. After about the first 7 levels, you finally gain access to a lightsaber. I was hoping this would be the point where the game turned itself around and really became fun to play. I was wrong. See, the thing about nostalgia is that it warps your view of how things ARE because you remember them as they WERE. This is very much an old game, and it definitely plays like one. Lightsaber combat is clunky and unenjoyable. Platforming segments can get ridiculous to try and complete (especially after you have gained the lightsaber), because Kyle Katarn (main character) is more busy doing Jedi flips over enemies when he jumps than actually following the jump like he's supposed to. There was one section where I died 39 times on one platform because Kyle liked to flip into electrically charged floors instead of onto the box where he needed to go. Turns out if you unequip the lightsaber, he jumps normally again. Often times, the only way I could get forward was to play as a force-jumping mercenary, then as an actual Jedi. For a game that's supposed to make you feel badass as a Jedi, this isn't good. In fact, there were several sections in the game where even finding the path forward to advance the story was nearly impossible without a guide. While I enjoy The Legend of Zelda's blend of action and puzzle solving, this isn't at all like that. These aren't puzzles with solutions that can be understood with enough time. These are backtracking and running all over the map to try and find the ONE PLACE that you are supposed to jump on to get to the next level. It became extremely frustrating when I'd killed all the enemies, then spent another hour looking for where the hell to go next. The story is nothing to write home about. A T-Rex looking alien uses the Valley of the Jedi to give all his followers force powers (which is how you can actually fight other lightsaber users). The voice acting is alright, but nothing special. There's a number of characters from the Original Trilogy to make it try and feel part of the Universe. But back to the combat. Fighting lightsaber wielding villians is the most fun to be had. When both you and your opponent have force powers, it becomes an entirely different game. A fun one. When the enemies don't have lightsaber, Kyle still treats them like they do, and so it becomes a game of getting close enough to the Stormtroopers to have your hit count. Also, the stormtroopers can take more than 1 lightsaber slice to them. IDK how, but they do. Later in the game, they change their armor to repel lightsabers making you have to resort back to: you guessed it, a force-jumping mercenary. So while, this game might have been great when it came out, it now looks, plays, sounds, and feels like a very old game. And not even a charming old like Baldur's Gate. (BTW, if you do purchase this, SAVE OFTEN. There's no autosave, so if you die, you can potentially lose hours, depending on where you last saved.)As a huge Star Wars fan, and pretty intensive gamer, I really wanted this to be good, but I just can't justify the purchase. Maybe on May the 4th when it's really discounted, but definitely not before (unless you played it as a kid on GameCube and have nothing but fond memories)Grade: 4/10

content:
r 5, 2016
												First time ever playing this game, and oh boy, wasn't a thrilling ride.Story wise, its fine.  Its Star Wars.  A fallen Jedi wants to rule the universe, and you have to stop him.  What more do you need or want.  What I wanted though is either the reason modern games are better, or maybe dumbed down.  Directions was what I wanted.  Many, MANY times I got lost.  Backtracking trying to find where to go.  Then you'd really search round a room and find that vent which blends into the background. A few times, had to use YouTube just to figure out where to go, which isn't a great selling point.  Suppose that was what made some old games great?The fighting with lightsabers is much improved in Jedi Academy I feel.  Although both games do lack in feedback, to know if you're dealing any damage.  Some fights I'd have 100 health, and swing about, jumping, trying to land shots then out of no where, two swings from the bad guy and death.  And this was me playing on Easy mode to begin with (yes I'm rubbish at gaming, who cares?).  Other times though, swing and he staggers, a jump on his head and he falls over dead.  Very inconsistent I found.  The gun play is alright.  You realise why Stormtroopes can't shoot when the guns themselves have terrible aim.For a 2002 game, it holds up not too bad.  If you're a Star Wars fan, then you might get some enjoyment out of it.  If you're a person who wants to wave lightsabers about in epic badassery...  I just don't think this game covers it, sorry.For level design, be prepared to be a little frustrated if you've never played before.  If you've played it back in the past, and wanting to pick it up again, just ask yourself as you're playing "How do the troops actually get into this room?", because many times the room they're in will have no doors, no ladders and be suspended over bottomless pits.  You're able to sneak in through a vent or something, but is that the route Mr Stormtrooper or Imperial Guard has to go to get to work??  I'm only not recommending this game, because I personnaly found it frustrating.  If Steam had a "maybe" option, I'd choose that instead.

content:
er 30, 2016
												I really want to enjoy this game, it has some great elements, the fps combat is decent, the lightsaber combat is fun, the story is interesting enough to want to see all the way through. But there is some lacking elements that I don't think makes this a great computer game. I'm not the greatest computer gamer out there but I'm not unfamiliar with computer controls. This game has me switching from mouse to trackpad depending if i want to fire my weapon or look around. if you're on mac be prepared to reassign force powers to different keys. the controls always seem to be fighting against you in combat, but it can be gotten used to. but probably the most unforgiving thing about this game is checkpoints and saving. checkpoints are rare, but you can save whenever and just reload your save whenever you die or think you can get through a section easier without losing shields or health. for the first few levels its workable. Then you get to Nar Shaaddaa, you have a lightsaber (though you won't use it too much the first level with it) and all seems like its looking up. then comes the difficulty spike of having to deal with snipers that can see you from a mile away and you can barely see them in your draw distance without taking a few shots to figure out where they are. This level is what really breaks the game for me, because after every sniper or sections of guys i deal with, i'm having to stop and save, because if i don't ill get blind sided by a sniper i can't see from way above me and I'll die. i don't mine unfair games. but having to constantly save, it breaks immersion, and now its just become a chore instead of a game. the only good thing i can say about it, is the price i got for it, which was a little over 2 dollars. if its a classic for you, something from you childhood, go grab it. especially if you're more used to computer controls or have a controller or something that will make the controls less wonky. but for everyone else, it's not that worth it.

content:
ry 21
												This game has great lightsaber combat.At least that's what they say. I gave up on the game before I ever got a lightsaber.The only real reason for this is because I couldn't get past level two, not because of the enemies, but instead because of the terrible level design. Maybe people who grew up in the days of layberinth-like first-person shooters will like this game, but people who are new enough to gaming to not play through this era will find a lot of difficulty. A lot of things don't make sense, like requiring you to find areas and paths that are so well hidden they would be too much even for a secret area. sometimes you'll see little bits of architecture that turn out to be REQUIRED to go through in order to finish the level. And if that wasn't bad enough, there was at least one time I can remember that following this logic led me to a death trap.Speaking of which, there are death traps EVERYWHERE! You need to quicksave constantly, since the checkpoints aren't very well laid out. I once spent around an hour stumbling through level one, when I came across an elevator. I pressed the button to send it up, but it wasn't going up. A few seconds later I realized it was above me because I was crushed to death by it, and sent back to the first five minutes of the level because that was the last checkpoint and I hadn't saved.I've heard this game has some great lightsaber combat, and a pretty decent story, I've heard it gets better at some point, but why bother slogging through all this terrible design when you can get Jedi Academy which has slightly better graphics, improved design in nearly every aspect, and lets you wield a lightsaber and force powers from the very start? This game has not aged as well as many other reviews will tell you, and if you don't have nostalgic feelings for this game from playing it when it came out, you will have a very difficult time enjoying it today.

content:
er 30, 2014
												For what it is worth, I never got around to playing this game back in the day.. Played Dark Forces, Jedi Knight I, and Jedi Knight III. I've heard great things about it, but... it's really broken on modern machines. Like, entirely broken, unable to function properly if you have certain configurations, and impossible to fix. The game is clunky, likes to crash, doesn't deal with widescreen well, and after a few hours of trying to get it to cooperate cleanly, I gave up. I know there is a quality FPS experience to be had here, but I don't happen to have a copy of XP with an older computer laying around. I've seen people get the game running, and I know there are guides to get it running cleanly, but I never quite got around to trying to make it work, despite following PCGamingWiki, steam forums, and other sources of information. Did a few .ini things, played with some config files, tried unofficial patches, and then I eventually gave up after it crashed when I opened a door. I came to find out that It doesn't work, period, if you have a newer AMD card with newer drivers (Catalsyt 13.2 or higher), no matter what you do. It doesn't like to cooperate with multi-cored systems. If you try to play it in widescreen, the FOV will get messed up, and if you try to adjust the FOV, you'll crash randomly. If you try to rebind keys, you might end up with a white screen. If you try to run it in a compatibility mode, it'll either work fine (If you have an NVIDIA card) or it'll hard-lock your computer. If you happen to have an older laptop laying around, or an old desktop for whatever reason, you should be fine. If you have an NVIDIA GPU rather than an AMD GPU, you should also be okay, I think. I can't personally test it. I do sincerely wish I could play it, but I can't recommend it in the state it is in. It's an old game that doesn't want to work properly, unfortunately. Every other Jedi Knight game plays relatively well, but this one just doesn't like to work... Although Dark Forces 2 likes to run in hyperspeed sometimes. But, that's for another review.

												This game is a prequel to the first game and you do not create your own chatacter. It is good but a little bit underwhelming when compared to the first game. The level design is in my opinion the best part of the game, however there are many times where you are not quite sure what to do next and it can get frustrating without any help from the internet. Also if you want to play this game for the lightsabers and not for the guns you might also be disappointed, since you will only receive your lightsaber after 1/3 of the game. However there are still many factors in the game that made the original great. I recommend to get the first game instead of this one, but it is still good   Jedi Outcast 9/10     Jedi Outcast 2:  7,5/10

content:
er 28, 2013
												(EDIT: I was under the apparently mistaken impression that Jedi Academy came first. That was a mistake on my part when I made a comparison at one point.)(EDIT 2: I have posted a video at the bottom that very briefly demonstrates the shifting position of the crosshair.)It's time to face an uncomfortable truth: no game is perfect. I tried as hard as I could to enjoy Jedi Outcast, and I tried more than once. It's unfortunate, but if you are curious about what problems this game might have, you are about to find them all listed in one place.One of my first irritations was trying to aim. Your reticle does not stay in the center of the screen: it shifts between the center and the lower right corner depending on the distance of your target. This greatly complicates aiming. Many enemies move around wildly, and your weapons have very slow moving projectiles that usually don't do much damage unless you can get one of those exceptionally tricky headshots. Both you and your target will be moving, so when you combine that with the shifting reticle and slow projectiles, hitting anything at all is an extreme challenge. I have often missed targets at nearly point blank range because the reticle was never where I expected it to be. Bear in mind that you will be shooting for the first large chunk of the game.One of the most appealling aspects of the game is lightsaber combat. And I found that to be little more fun than shooting. The very first level after you get your lightsaber pits you against snipers -which can't be blocked with your lightsaber- and grenadiers -which your lightsaber not only doesn't protect you against, but I remember it actually detonating the grenades. Timing your swings is tricky, so you might take a shot before you actually kill your target. And then there is lightsaber vs lightsaber combat. And I was never able to figure that out. (This coming from a lover of Dark Messiah of Might and Magic and Severence: Blade of Darkness.) The Jedi Outcast tries to replicate the look of (highly correographed) lightsaber combat in the movies, and what we get is hard to read. What I would end up doing was trying to always keep the enemy in front of me and keep using force heal. By the way, do you remember those attacks your lightsaber won't protect you from? Like explosives and sniper shots? Enemies with lightsabers are immune to such attacks from you.Force powers try to spice combat up. But gone are force choke, force drain, and other useful abilities from Jedi Acadamy. (Not to mention the ability to immediately level up your force heal and skip the very worst levels.) In fact, you get less combos in general than you did in Jedi Academy. Jedi Outcast features the most monumentally confusing level design I have ever seen. It is clear that none of the levels were designed to be like a place that would have had an actual function for actual people before your character shows up. Rather, levels tend to be slightly abstract. One problem is that there are often several similar rooms copied and pasted together, making environments more confusing and repetitive. Jedi Outcast delights in making it unclear what you have to do to progress through the game. I would literally get stuck for 30 minutes and then achieve progress only by shooting a random thing out of my frustration or boredom. There were usually no visual cues at all that I was supposed to shoot said thing, and these incidents happened many times. I have said before that if Valve designed these levels, there would be honorable suicides taking place.And now for the most frustrating mechanic by far in the game, the mandatory stealth section. If one enemy sees you and presses an alarm, you immediately get a cutscene of Mr. Katarn getting executed. There was literally no reason that I couldn't have sliced out everyone's nipples except the game wanting to pis me off. This section contains the type of hyperlinear gameplay executing the player for not guessing what specific thing they had to do to avoid execution that frustrates me in modern military shooter campaigns. The elephant in this particular room is that stealth mechanics don't really exist in Jedi Outcast. As Kyle announced the beggining of the mandatory stealth section, my already high frustration immediately spiked yet higher. At my first feel of this section, I immediately decided that the game had tested my patience in too many other ways, so I cheated past that part in the hope that the game would begin to get fun after that.It never did. I reached a point where I fought three lightsaber wielding enemies simultaneously, and I gave up. I'm pretty sure the game was not going to get better after that point, and even if it did it would be far too late for that.Shooting is broken, lightsaber combat is broken, and level design is broken. What is left? Storyline? First off, the enjoyability of a game's story is always going to be bottlenecked by the quality of the gameplay because you must play the game to progress through the story. Ignoring that, what is the story? That joke of a leftover empire does things, and we contrive a way to have an army of red lightsaber wielders. Just like in Jedi Academy. And this constantly contriving armies of red lightsaber wielders in Star Wars games rings a bit as B.S.Every time I try to play it again, I always rediscover frustrations that I hadn't quite commited to memory; there are too many for me to remember all of them. I literally consider Jedi Outcast to be the worst first person shooter I have ever played. (Haven't played Revelations 2012, Rogue Warrior, or Garry's Incident mind you.)Now, the vast majority of players say this game is awesome, and it has nearly a top tier metacritc score. For those reasons, I can't guarantee that you will hate this game like I do. But if you do pick up Jedi Outcast and find it to be one of your most frustrating experiences in gaming, I just want you to know that I called it.Here's that wierd thing the crosshair does:


YouTube™ Video: Crosshair Movement in Star Wars Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast (Why is this a thing?) 

			Views: 568		

			I created this video to demonstrate my number one problem with Jedi Outcast, which is the shifting position of the targeting reticule.

, 2014
												There isn't to be said that Jedi Knight 2 it's a bad game, however, it just isn't my cup of tea.The game presents itself as well as Jedi Academy did (the sequel) the graphics seem good for the time beign, there's force powers, and the promise of traversing to wonderful and unique levels in the Star Wars universe. It doesn't go that well, the main problem it's the level design and overall level quality, for a game that it's obsessed with making "maze like levels" they just aren't that intuitive and it almost seems like the designers tried to deliberatly make the game much more complex that what it needed to be, but it it's the complexity the one that drives me crazy, it's the way it's executed, the game never tries to be friendly with the player, it always force you down to absurd and tedious cutscenes that don't add anything new, the characters are never present and because of this you never really develop any kind of simpathy for them. It seems that it wasn't until it's sequel when the designers realize a different more, "easy and simple", approach.There were literally times that made me wish to just turn the game off and go do something that wasn't as tedious or annoying as getting lost constantly into the gigantic levels. It just never feels smart or seductive, it just follows a pattern of self destruction that doesn't lead to nothing more than the absurd desire of creating mind bendling puzzles into the mind of the player, however this are not the kind of ones that i like, and they probrably never will.

content:
er 27, 2016
												On it's own, this game is an amazing Star Wars experience: a classic from a bygone era. However, once you activate g_saberrealisticcombat from the command line, this timeless staple of Star Wars lore of yore becomes the greatest Star Wars game to date. Relive the adventures of the man who stole the Death Star plans and found the Valley of the Jedi in this quintessential Star Wars masterpiece.

, 2013
												The adventures of everyone’s favorite Kyle Katarn continue in another thrilling Jedi Knight game.  And who doesn’t love Kyle anyways?  He’s often been referred to as the Chuck Norris of Star Wars.  And to people that care about Chuck Norris that probably means something.  For me personally, Kyle as seen in these games is more annoying that the Kyle you read about in many of the books.But I’m not reviewing the latest Fate of the Jedi book, is that series still popular?  I’m way behind on my Star Wars novels unfortunately.  We’re here to talk about the next in the Jedi Knight series, Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast.  This time Kyle is back, and what starts with a blue milk run quickly becomes a quest fueled by anger and revenge.As the Wikipedia blurb said, assuming anybody actually reads those, Jedi Outcast uses the Quake III: Team Area engine.  This means we are guaranteed to have a pretty good looking game, ID Tech III was first seen in Quake III Arena back in 1999.  It was a beautiful game then, and personally is still a beautiful game.  While there will always be things that could be picked at about the engine, and all the games that run on it, it will remain in my book as one of the best looking engines out there.Jedi Outcast starts off kinda slow, but does pick up its pace once you get your hands on your lightsaber.  Which for me took about 4 hours.  I’m not going to lie, I had a really tough time with this game for some reason.  I’ve played it through in the past, but long enough ago that everything was still new to me.  In fact it wasn’t until I got the lightsaber that I realized that I had in fact play Jedi Outcast.Something about the combat mechanics didn’t agree with me, and while there were some valid complaints.  Things like the Imperial Officers take more damage than the Stormtroopers.  Stormtroopers that are wearing armor while the Officers simply have their dress uniforms.  It would appear that a cotton polyester blend can withstand blaster fire better than the standard issue plastoid armor.  Someone should tell Requisitions about this, could save the Empire billions of credits.You know that line from A New Hope?  Where Ben Kenobi says that a lightsaber isn’t as clumsy or random as a blaster.  Thereby implying that blasters are both clumsy and random.  Well it seems like the developers took that line from the movie and placed it at the core of their combat mechanics.  You could fire a blaster six times without moving the mouse and you’ll hit at six different locations.  The blasters have a fan effect, one that is made worse if you use the rapid-fire.While the previous games had a similar fanning of the blaster bolts, they also had an auto-aim that counter balanced it.  You didn’t have to be a perfect shot, the blaster would make up for what you lacked in skill.  Here they’ve done away with the auto-aim, but left the fanning.  Personally, I don’t think Ben was being very literal when he made that statement.  Not to the extent that this game makes it seem.The story I’d call above average, but still falls to some standard video game issues.  As with many games there are aspects or parts of the story that feel like they are only there for something to do.  Otherwise, were it simply a written story, the segment would have been left out.  But I’d can’t blame a game for these moments, as all games tend to have them.  The developers want to keep the action up, or to showcase a specific feature or ability in the game, and write a level into the story just for that purpose.  Its a common trait, and one that we games have gotten used to.  And the better writers and developers can do this, and blend it into the story so well that we tend to not even notice it on the first pass.Jedi Outcast has the expected character cameos of Luke Skywalker, Mon Mothma, Jan Ors, and Lando Calrissian.  And best of all is that Billy Dee Williams actually voiced Lando, giving the character a little more love than the others.  Although it was a pretty big coincidence that Kyle should happen to be stranded in the same place where Lando is locked up.But convenient coincidences aside, the story holds it own with the average of today.  As well as the bulk of the gameplay, controls, and puzzles have all aged well.  The blasters could use a little work, and perhaps a texture update and you have something that beats a lot of today’s releases.  In fact this would be a great game to get a HD remake.  And there are probably a couple of other things that I just can’t think of right now, but I guess they’re not that important.

												Understand one thing before you play this game: the early game sucks.  You don't have your lightsaber, you don't have force powers, and the levels are labyrinthine at times, requiring you to find air ducts and switches in the middle of rooms. 10, 2014
												The sequel to 1997's Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II, Jedi Outcast provides an adventurous, bold continuation of the series, while staying true to the core exploratory and FPS combat experience that the Dark Forces series has become known for. While the AI of enemies remains mediocre, the sheer visceral nature of the gameplay, particularly the fluid, acutely-controlled lightsaber combat and the brilliant authenticity of the sights and sounds of the Star Wars universe should suck in any player with even a remote interest in the film series, granting a playthrough chock-full of fast-paced, against-the-odds combat that will leave everyone craving more. In contrast to the standalone expansion pack Mysteries of the Sith, Jedi Outcast's story is relatively concrete. Kyle Katarn, left war of the dark side of the Force, gives up his Jedi powers, remaining a mercenary for the fledging New Republic with his partner, Jan Ors. When Jan is taken from him, however, Kyle returns to Luke Skywalker's Jedi Academy and takes up a lightsaber once more, taking on the Imperial Remnant and uncovering that threatens to overthrow the Republic and crush the fledging New Jedi Order.If you're looking for an authentic, brilliant Star Wars game, it's hard to recommend anything other than the Jedi Knight series, and this game in particular. Though the Quake 3 engine had indeed aged quite a bit, the game should run relatively well on modern platforms. And hey, if you're eager for more Force-wielding action? Forget The Force Unleashed; pick up Jedi Academy and sink your teeth in.

y 2, 2014
												this is the first star wars anything i ever experianced and the fact that a game from lucas arts is better then the entire prequel crap fest is water under the bridge. this game is great i never found the graphics a problem ; they are just good enough to look retro but not dated. they are just perfect. the level design is top notch with secrets and large non linear areas like doom. the multiplayer is better then quake ever will be and is the best arena style fps game. the soundtrack is amazing making this feel like a legitimate star wars entry. it is only held back by a frew infuirating puzzles and some FIND THE SWITCH WHILE GETTING SHOT AT FROM EVERYWHERE moments but even those can be fun when you whip out the ol' lightsaber and slice up some fun. the saber combat is amzing fyi. it has 3 modes a lot of cool combo moves you need to learn to pull of and has a stagerring amount of depth. its even reminds me of the combat in dark souls , methodical with quick jabs and positioning being key as opposed to running in and bashing ♥♥♥♥ about. the first levels do a great job introducing the rock solid shooting mechanics and the level desing is top notch. it paces itself super well. it takes hours to finally get a lightsaber and when you do you apreciate the power you weild. and the forces powers a great. choking enemies then dropping them off a cliff will never get old but they feel more accurate then force unleashed. overall best star wars game ever, and 2nd best licensed game every (arkham city takes 1) 10/10 amazing and it runs on just abount anything to boot

												High difficulty level aside, this is a great First Person Shooter set in the Star Wars universe. Granted the story isn't anything amazing, but it tells you more about the character of Kyle Katarn and how he fits into the Star Wars universe. There may be a few better Star Wars games out there that expand the overall lore (Knights Of The Old Republic), but this game is definitely worth your time, especially at the price it is. Also the chance to feel like a Jedi and a trooper at the same time by wielding a lightsaber and a blaster: Always a plus.Recommended.

er 2, 2016
Product received for free
Disclaimer : I got this game for almost nothing in some Star Wars Humble Bundle that i bought for other games a few year back, that's why i'm considering i got the game for free (probably for less than 0.25€)I hadn't played this game for more than 10 years... A friend lent me the game back then, but i never finished it. When i noticed it in my Steam library this week-end so i decided to give it another try. The game is a blend of FPS and third person lightsaber combat. Weapons feel responsive, sound great, and carry the nostalgia of these early-2000s Star Wars games. The graphics are not bad, they aged well in my opinion and i'm genuinely still amazed by the marks left by lightsabers on walls.Now for the cons :* First it's clearly not worth 10€ in 2016.* Some game mechanics are NOT introduced, i discovered that i could use objects, after being stuck for half an hour in the only part of the game that really require using them (The nightvision goggles in the hangar level). Moreover, i only discovered during the final level that i could heal myself using a force power. (Explaining why the last levels were so hard, since medipacs were not provided anymore as i was supposed to use the force...) * Talking about levels, they seem well designed at first glance, but they are a labyrinthic mess. Prepare to run around levels you just cleared for hours before finding out an utterly hidden ventilation grid on the ceiling of a random room that will lead to the next part of it. This happens in every level and i wasn't prepared for that. I still can't believe some levels of this game made it through QA and play-testing, as half of them require you to perform jumps that would have been considered as glitch/skips in any decently-designed game.TL;DR : This is overall a good experience, but kinda frustrating if you are used to modern games that have corrected the youthful errors of this one over a decade. 6.5/10
